Dear Madam:
div1.p:
In a “Memorandum for the President,” dated Washington,
Aug. 30, 1906, Brig.-Gen. R.M. O'Reilly, Surgeon General, U. S.
Army, speaking of the service rendered by Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, a
member of the Yellow Fever Commission, says:

“ Mrs. Lazear receives from Congress a pension of
$17. a month with $2. additional for each of two minor
children until they reach the age of 16.”
The paper referred to further states:

“It is believed that this recognition on the part
of the Nation for his services is utterly inadequate. His
widow's pension should be increased to $100. a month.” X X X

This Association, whose membership represents the commer-
cial interests of the Metropolis, feels as strongly as does Surgeon
General O'Reilly that the country at large, and the mercantile com-
munity in particular, owe an everlasting debt of gratitude for the
work performed by Dr. Lazear in the mosquito experiments conducted
in Cuba. Every person in the United States should be thankful
for the results achieved by the Commission. The saving to trade
and commerce by the control of this most dreaded disease is incal-
culable. Holding these views, our Executive Committee, at the
suggestion of a number of our members, wishes to exert its influence,
if desired, in the endeavor to have the appreciative sentiments of
the people of the Republic given expression to in this matter in a
Mrs. Jesse W. Lazear,
- 2 -
practical and fitting manner. In order that proper recognition
of the noble sacrifice made by Dr. Lazear, in the service of his
country and in the interest of science, may be shown by Congress,
or otherwise, we take the liberty of requesting from you at your
early convenience a statement of your present financial condition
and the sources of income for the support of yourself and your
children. Though reluctant to do so, inability to secure the de-
sired and necessary information through the War Department compels
us to address you direct, feeling certain, however, that the spirit
of our writing will be understood by you.
With expressions of esteem, we remain,

closer.signed:
THE MERCHANTS' ASSOCIATION OF NEW YORK,
By RC Mead
Secretary.
